name: Droperidol (Inapsine)
summary: A butyrophenone antipsychotic primarily used for postoperative nausea/vomiting and agitation in emergency settings.
description: Droperidol is a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist of the butyrophenone class, related to haloperidol. While historically used as an antipsychotic, it is now most often employed in anesthesia and emergency medicine for rapid control of agitation and for prevention of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV). Its use has declined due to concerns about QT prolongation and risk of torsades de pointes.

sections.text: Antagonizes dopamine D2 receptors in the chemoreceptor trigger zone and mesolimbic pathway, reducing nausea and agitation. Also exhibits alpha-adrenergic blockade.

adult.agitation: 2.5–10 mg IM/IV, may repeat every 15–30 minutes as needed
adult.nausea_vomiting: 0.625–1.25 mg IV/IM administered at induction or end of surgery

sections.geriatric: Lower initial doses (e.g., 0.625 mg for nausea, 2.5 mg for agitation)

items: Injection: 2.5 mg/mL (2 mL and 10 mL vials)

sections.text: Onset within 3–10 minutes (IV) or 10–30 minutes (IM); duration 2–4 hours.

sections.black_box: Droperidol may cause QT prolongation and serious arrhythmias, including torsades de pointes. ECG monitoring is recommended.
other: Avoid in patients with prolonged QT interval

items: Continuous cardiac monitoring if high risk

sections.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks; safety data limited
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; use with caution
sections.pediatrics: Not routinely recommended except in anesthesia under specialist care
sections.geriatrics: Increased sensitivity to hypotension and sedation

items: Rapid onset makes it useful in emergency agitation management
Often used in combination with benzodiazepines for severe agitation
Has both antiemetic and sedative properties
